title: Dynamic data analysis with Shiny
text:
Adjustement of logistic model (Verhulst)
We consider the logistic model used to describe population growth.
\[
\frac{dN}{dt} = rN \left( 1 - \frac{N}{K} \right)
\] whose solution is given by:
\[
N(t) = \frac{K}{1 + \left(\frac{K - N_0}{N_0}\right) e^{-rt}}
\] Where:


N(t) is the population size at time t.

K is the carrying capacity.

r is the intrinsic growth rate.

\(N_0\) is the initial population size at time t=0.

title: Exercises
text:
Exercises 1: logistic model

Goal: convert the code located at ./assets/1_shiny/logistic/verhulst.R into a Shiny app.

library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)

# Read and transform data
ver <- read.table(
  "http://pbil.univ-lyon1.fr/R/donnees/VerhulstPF1847.txt",
  sep = "\t",
  header = TRUE
) |> mutate(obs = obs / 10^6, theo = theo / 10^6)

t0 <- ver$t[1]
N0 <- ver$obs[1]

# Model equations
logistic <- function(t, p) {
  with(as.list(p), {
    K / (1 + ((K - N0)/N0) * exp(-r*(t-t0)))
  })
}

# Minimize
sce <- function(p) {
  theo <- sapply(ver$t, logistic, p = setNames(p, c("r", "K")))
  return(sum((ver$obs - theo)^2))
}

# Fit: K = 5 means 5 millions people max (*10^6)
nlmfit <- nlm(f = sce, p = c(0.02, 5))

# Calculate model with predicted coefficients
tseq <- seq(from = 1800, to = 2000, by = 1)
res <- data.frame(
  t = tseq,
  y = logistic(tseq, p = setNames(nlmfit$estimate, c("r", "K")))
)

# Add linear model alternative
lm_coef <- coef(lm(ver$obs ~ ver$t))

# Plot everything
ggplot(data = res) +
  geom_line(mapping = aes(x = t, y = y)) +
  geom_point(
    data = ver,
    mapping = aes(x = t, y = obs), color = "lightblue"
  ) +
  geom_abline(
    slope = lm_coef[2],
    intercept = lm_coef[1],
    color = "pink"
  ) +
  labs(
    x = "Year",
    y = "Population in million",
    title = "Population growth in belgium"
  )









Create an app.R file with this template:

library(shiny)

ui <- fluidPage(
  
)

server <- function(input, output, session) {
  
}

shinyApp(ui, server)

Within the ui object, create 2 input widgets for r and K parameters. You can use ?shiny::numericInput for guidance.
Importantly, anything that isn‚Äôt reactive can live outside the server function like the logistic function definition and other objects:

logistic <- function(t, p) {
  with(as.list(p), {
    K / (1 + ((K - N0)/N0) * exp(-r*(t-t0)))
  })
}
...

In the server object, create a reactive that fits the model to the data and returns the model predicted values:

res <- reactive({
  # Replace <INPUT_1>, <INPUT_2> by what is defined in ui
  nlmfit <- nlm(f = sce, p = c(<INPUT_1>, <INPUT_2>))

  # Calculate model with predicted coefficients
  data.frame(
    t = tseq,
    y = logistic(tseq, p = setNames(nlmfit$estimate, c("r", "K")))
  )
})

In the server object use the res reactive expression to plot the data:

# Replace TBD by what is relevant
output$<TBD> <- render<TBD>({
  ggplot(data = <TBD>) +
  geom_line(mapping = aes(x = t, y = y)) +
  geom_point(
    data = ver,
    mapping = aes(x = t, y = obs), color = "lightblue"
  ) +
  geom_abline(
    slope = lm_coef[2],
    intercept = lm_coef[1],
    color = "pink"
  ) +
  labs(
    x = "Year",
    y = "Population in million",
    title = "Population growth in belgium"
  )
})
Don‚Äôt forget to add the corresponding *Output container in the ui part. 5. Try to run the app.

title: Dynamic data analysis with Shiny
text:
Complete Exercise 1
We define the following objective function, \(y_i\) being the observed data and \(f(x_i, \beta)\) the model predictions:
\[
S(\beta) = \sum_{i=1}^{n} (y_i - f(x_i, \beta))^2
\] We want to minimize this:
\[
\hat{\beta} = \arg \min_{\beta} \sum_{i=1}^{n} (y_i - f(x_i, \beta))^2
\]
